<nitpicking mode on>
I don't think that the capacity to build sharp frontie=
rs is a real issue. A good old sigmoid applied to a linear combination of t=
he chemicals concentration of each cells, and voila... 

Also the usual "wa=
llpaper look" of the reaction-diffusion systems is due to the fact that mos=
t of the time, they are integrated over a torus domain. Using different bou=
ndary conditions (like 'all 0' borders) completely remove that "wallpaper l=
ook". 
</nitpicking mode on>

Regards,
Alexandre Devert

            Alexandre, thank you for br=
inging up reaction-diffusion systems.  You

make a good point- my statement=
 was too broad, in part because

"cellular growth model" is a fairly ambigu=
ous term that can

potentially refer to many types of systems.  



Just to=
 clarify my statement, I was responding the line of discussion

with Peter =
about encodings that actually create distinct bodily shapes

that are self-=
contained and have clear structural boundaries (which

reaction-diffusion s=
ystems tend not to produce; rather they produce

wallpaper-like patterns). =
 Often when growth-based models are used to

define actual bodies with dist=
inct borders, they are studied in the

context of blobs with a particular f=
ocus on how the blob knows when to

stop growing so that a border shape can=
 be created.  That kind of

systems goes along with the "skin" issue that w=
e were discussing.



Nevertheless, the field is quite broad and there are =
many possible

interesting examples of such systems.  If I could revisit my=


statement, I would reword it such as to avoid implying any sweeping

gene=
ralization.



ken
